segments.text:
Now, in Fortran, the main program would look like:

program codeforces_500_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, goal, i
    integer, allocatable :: arr(:)
    logical :: isFound

    read(*, *) n, goal
    allocate(arr(n-1)) read(*, *) arr(1:n-1)
    isFound = dfs(1, arr, goal)
    if (isFound) then
        print *, "YES"
    else
        print *, "NO"
    end if
    deallocate(arr)
end program

But wait, the initial code in Java uses a scanner to read the next integers. So in Fortran, the read statement would read the entire line. So if the input is given as a single line, the read(*, *) n, goal will read them.
segments.label: language_mapping

segments.text: Then, the next line contains n-1 integers.
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text: Or perhaps all inputs are on a single line?

segments.text:
The original Java code uses a Scanner which reads input as space-separated tokens. So in Fortran, the code should read all inputs correctly. But in Fortran, when using read(*, *), it reads from standard input, consuming the required values. So the code should work. Now, the dfs function:

recursive function dfs(currpos, arr, target) result(res)
    integer, intent(in) :: currpos, target
    integer, intent(in) :: arr(:)
    logical :: res
    integer :: next_pos

    if (currpos == target) then
        res = .true.
    else if (currpos == size(arr) + 1) then
        res = .false. else
        next_pos = currpos + arr(currpos)
        res = dfs(next_pos, arr, target) if (res) return
        res = .false.
    end if
end function

Wait, but in the Java code, after the teleport, if it returns true, then return true. Otherwise, return false. So in the Java code, the line:

boolean teleport = dfs(...);
if (teleport) return true;
return false;

Which is equivalent to return teleport. So the code can be simplified to return dfs(...);. But in Java, the code is written as:

teleport = dfs(...);
if (teleport) return true;
return false;

Which is the same as return teleport;. So in Fortran, after computing res = dfs(...), then if res is true, return. Otherwise, return false. So the code can be written as:

res = dfs(...) if (res) then
    return
end if
res = .false. But in the else block of the function. Wait, the code in the else clause (when currpos is not target and not size(arr)+1) would be:

next_pos = currpos + arr(currpos)
res = dfs(next_pos, arr, target) if (res) then
    return
else
    res = .false.
end if

Wait, but in the Java code, after the teleport call, if teleport is true, returns true, else returns false. So the code returns the value of teleport. So in Fortran, that can be written as:

res = dfs(next_pos, arr, target) So the entire else block would be:

else
    next_pos = currpos + arr(currpos)
    res = dfs(next_pos, arr, target)
end if

Wait, but the Java code returns whatever dfs returns. So why does the Java code have if (teleport) return true; else return false? Because that's redundant.
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text:
The code could just return teleport. But the original code is written that way. For example, in Java:

boolean teleport = dfs(...);
if (teleport) return true;
return false;

Which is equivalent to return teleport;. So in Fortran, in the else clause, after calculating next_pos, call dfs and set res to that result. So the code in the else block would be:

next_pos = currpos + arr(currpos) res = dfs(next_pos, arr, target) Thus, the Fortran function would be:

recursive function dfs(currpos, arr, target) result(res)
    integer, intent(in) :: currpos, target
    integer, intent(in) :: arr(:)
    logical :: res
    integer :: next_pos

    if (currpos == target) then
        res = .true.
    else if (currpos == size(arr) + 1) then
        res = .false. else
        next_pos = currpos + arr(currpos)
        res = dfs(next_pos, arr, target)
    end if
end function

segments.text:
So, the code for the function can be written as:

recursive function dfs(currpos, arr, target) result(res)
    integer, intent(in) :: currpos, target
    integer, intent(in) :: arr(:)
    logical :: res
    integer :: next_pos

    if (currpos == target) then
        res = .true.
    else if (currpos == size(arr) + 1) then
        res = .false. else
        next_pos = currpos + arr(currpos)
        res = dfs(next_pos, arr, target)
    end if
end function

The Fortran code would be:

program codeforces_500_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, goal
    integer, allocatable :: arr(:)
    logical :: isFound

    read(*, *) n, goal
    allocate(arr(n-1))
    read(*, *) arr
    isFound = dfs(1, arr, goal) if (isFound) then
        print *, "YES"
    else
        print *, "NO"
    end if
    deallocate(arr)
contains
    recursive function dfs(currpos, arr, target) result(res)
        integer, intent(in) :: currpos, target
        integer, intent(in) :: arr(:)
        logical :: res
        integer :: next_pos

        if (currpos == target) then
            res = .true.
        else if (currpos == size(arr) + 1) then
            res = .false. else
            next_pos = currpos + arr(currpos)
            res = dfs(next_pos, arr, target)
        end if
    end function dfs
end program codeforces_500_A But there are a few syntax points to check:

- In Fortran, the array is declared as (n-1), and in the allocate statement, it's allocate(arr(n-1)).

-

program codeforces_500_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, goal, i
    integer, allocatable :: arr(:)
    logical :: isFound

    read(*, *) n, goal
    allocate(arr(n-1))
    read(*, *) arr(1:n-1)
    isFound = dfs(1, arr, goal)
    if (isFound) then
        print *, "YES"
    else
        print *, "NO"
    end if
    deallocate(arr)
end program

Now, the dfs function:

recursive function dfs(currpos, arr, target) result(res)
    integer, intent(in) :: currpos, target
    integer, intent(in) :: arr(:)
    logical :: res
    integer :: next_pos

    if (currpos == target) then
        res = .true.
    else if (currpos == size(arr) + 1) then
        res = .false.
    else
        next_pos = currpos + arr(currpos)
        res = dfs(next_pos, arr, target)
        if (res) return
        res = .false.
    end if
end function

recursive function dfs(currpos, arr, target) result(res)
    integer, intent(in) :: currpos, target

So putting it all together:

The Fortran code would be:

program codeforces_500_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, goal
    integer, allocatable :: arr(:)
    logical :: isFound

    read(*, *) n, goal
    allocate(arr(n-1))
    read(*, *) arr
    isFound = dfs(1, arr, goal)
    if (isFound) then
        print *, "YES"
    else
        print *, "NO"
    end if
    deallocate(arr)
contains
    recursive function dfs(currpos, arr, target) result(res)
        integer, intent(in) :: currpos, target
        integer, intent(in) :: arr(:)
        logical :: res
        integer :: next_pos

        if (currpos == target) then
            res = .true.
        else if (currpos == size(arr) + 1) then
            res = .false.
        else
            next_pos = currpos + arr(currpos)
            res = dfs(next_pos, arr, target)
        end if
    end function dfs
end program codeforces_500_A

But there are a few syntax points to check:

- In Fortran, the array is declared as (n-1), and in the allocate statement, it's allocate(arr(n-1)).

- In the read statement for arr, it's read(*, *) arr(1:n-1) or just arr, since it's allocated to size n-1.

- In the function, arr is declared as arr(:), which is an assumed-shape array, so the size is determined at runtime.

- The function is inside the contains section of the program, which allows it to have access to the variables in the program's scope. But in this case, the function is passed the necessary parameters, so it's okay.

But wait, in the code, the function is inside the program's contains section. So the function is part of the program, and has access to the program's variables. But the function's parameters are passed, so no problem.

But in the function, the line:

Which computes size(arr) as the size of the passed array. Since arr is declared as (n-1) in the program, size(arr) is n-1. So currpos == (n-1) +1 → currpos ==n.

So the code correctly checks if currpos is n.
